Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Bridging Game Theory, Economics and Computer Science: Equilibria, Fixed Points, and Beyond

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Internet is undoubtedly one of the most significant innovations of our era. Beyond serving as a medium of communication, it also enables huge opportunities for new markets and business. The study of the Internet and e-commerce has been one of the most exciting and challenging research areas in computer science during the past few decades. Recently, concepts and methodologies from game theory and economics have found numerous successful applications in this area.

The main goal of this proposal is to bridge the algorithmic gap between game theory, economics and computer science. While computational efficiency has always been a critical issue in the design of any computer system, the study within game theory and economics has been almost entirely non-algorithmic. The PI will work to develop efficient algorithms for some of the fundamental models and solution concepts and to understand the computational difficulties inherent within them, with the aim to inspire and enable the next-generation e-commerce systems.

For this purpose, the PI will perform a systematic study of both algorithmic and complexity-theoretic questions related to Nash equilibria and market equilibria. This includes the search of a polynomial-time approximation scheme for two-player Nash equilibria and the development of new techniques to understand the computation of market equilibria with various utility functions and with social influence. The PI will also work to improve our current understanding of PPAD and FIXP, two complexity classes for (discrete and continuous) fixed point computation, on which many of the hardness results of equilibrium computation rely. As two of the most fundamental solution concepts, the proposed research on Nash and market equilibria will contribute to a more solid algorithmic and complexity-theoretic foundation for the interdisciplinary field of Algorithmic Game Theory. Finally, the PI will tightly integrate education with the research activities by, e.g., developing new (introductory and advanced) courses on Algorithmic Game Theory and on its use in analyzing social networks; mentoring Ph.D. students; and promoting undergraduate research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The concept of equilibria has been widely studied in game theory and economics under various models, in order to characterize, understand and predict strategic behavior of selfish yet rational agents. During the past few decades, it has been a central tool in the study of the Internet and e-commerce in computer science. The goal of the proposal is to deepen our understanding of the computational complexity of equilibria. Below we describe some of the main results achieved along this direction.

First, the PI studies market equilibria under the classical exchange model of Arrow and Debreu, where a number of traders come to the market with their own goods and seek to exchange goods in order to maximize their own utilities. As one of the foundational results in general equilibrium theory, Arrow and Debreu showed that every market (under mild conditions) has a set of prices, one for each good in the market, that matches exactly the demand and supply and clears the market. The computational problem is then to find such a set of prices, called a market equilibrium. In a paper that appeared in JACM in 2017, the PI and coauthors make a major step towards a systematic understanding of what features make the equilibrium analysis of markets computationally hard.
To this end, we say that a market is "non-monotone" if it exhibits the following unusual phenomenon: At a certain set of prices, the demand of a good is at least as much as its supply and raising the price of this good strictly increases its demand. We show that the problem of finding a market equilibrium is intractable (under standard complexity-theoretic assumptions) for a family of markets if the latter contains a non-monotone market. Roughly speaking, our result implies that the market equilibrium problem is hard if some of the markets one aims to solve exhibit the unusual "non-monotone" phenomenon. This result significantly improves our understanding of the computational landscape of market equilibria, by covering a wide variety of well studied families of markets in economic theory. A more ambitious goal is to obtain a complete classification of markets into those that can be solved efficiently and those that are intractable. Ideas and techniques developed in our paper may help in future attacks on this problem.
Next, the PI studies Nash equilibria in multiplayer games. Nash showed in 1950 that every finite game has an equilibrium point at which no player can deviate unilaterally to improve his or her own utility. The computational problem of finding a Nash equilibrium has been studied intensively in computer science during the past decade. In a paper that appeared in STOC 2015, the PI and coauthors work on anonymous games, a natural and important class of succinct (meaning that such a game can be easily described) multiplayer games in which identities of players have no effect on utilities. We show that the problem of finding a Nash equilibrium in an anonymous game is intractable, giving an affirmative answer to a conjecture by Daskalakis and Papadimitriou. In contrast, it was shown earlier by Daskalakis and Papadimitriou and recent follow-up work that the problem becomes much easier if one is satisfied with an approximate equilibrium. In a recent paper that appeared in ITCS 2017, the PI and coauthors study the number of queries needed by any randomized algorithm that finds an approximate Nash equilibrium in a (general) multiplayer game. The lower bound we obtain essentially matches the known upper bound and answers an open problem posed by Hart and Nisan and by Babichenko. Our proof is based on a novel and simple reduction between two broadly used notions of approximate Nash equilibria, which might be of independent interest.
The project supported multiple PhD students in the CS department at Columbia University as well as the dissemination of their research results by funding them to attend top conferences in theoretical computer science.
